sect1.title: Let me first intrduce myself!
sect1.para: My name is Sigfrid Lundberg, research engineer and computer programmer within the Univertity's Library Network.
Over the years I have been working on diverse matters:

listitem.para: Harvesting and Web indexing
Resource discovery databases; metadata aware harvesting
A nation wide research information system (RIS) and a (similarly national) database for course information built using harvesting technology
Web archiving
Standardization work within (e.g.) DCMI. Member of DCMI Advisory Board.

sect1.para: In addition to these activities I participated in EU funded telematics projects, Desire, EUN, EUC, ETB.

listitem.para: Electronic publishing; Electronic theses and dissertations

sect1.title: Concentrating on text
sect1.para: Around 1999 I became involved digitization and Text Encoding and Interchange (TEI), and I also realized that what I had done for years actually had a name -- text technology. Before that and after I've been involved in:

listitem.para: Storing and retrieval of text
Indexing and searching for texts and withing texts; text mining
Text encoding, i.e., creation of HTML, SGML and XML documents.
Modelling of texts using DTDs and later schema languages, and validation of such texts
Type setting of encoded text

sect1.para: Much of these techniques are use in Humanities computing (e.g., creation digital critical editions of literary works), digitization, digital preservation and electronic publishing.

sect1.title: What do libraries do?
sect1.para: Libraries exists because they:

listitem.para: Collect,
Preserve,
Organize,
and provide access to information

sect1.para: Persons who knows or have experienced something may write about it The results are published. The publication is data and is stored as data in books, journals and possibly on hard disks, CDs etc.
Any corporate body storing published information is a library for sharing whithin its constituency is a library.

sect1.title: What is an archive?
sect1.para: An archive is information collected by persons or corporate bodies to document a process. The process can be a person's life or a university's research or a company's business.

sect1.title: Why preservation?
sect1.para: Knowledge is stored in brains
Only human beings may aquire knowledge. They do so through a cognitive process called learning. Obviously, we may can only do that from information that were created in the past.
There is one exception: When we do research we gain knowledge that has never hitherto been stored as information.

sect2.title: We can only gain knowledge from information that has been preserved.
sect2.para: If we don't preserve, then all all knowledge would have been gained through original research.

It is cost effective way for the society to keep its information, be it publications or archival records, in institutions that collect, preserve, organize and provide access to information for their constituencies.

sect1.title: What is digital preservation?
sect1.para: You may engage in digital preservation for two reasons:

listitem.para: You have older media (on paper) and want a digital backup and by provide digital access you can lock up the fragile originals.
Your have born digital media and want to preserve those for the future.

sect1.para: All preservation (be it digital or conventional) is based on human efforts. It requires software, storage servers, hard disks, tape backup etc, and a lot of computing. It is a question of workflows...
There exists a specification of an Open Archival Information Service, which is an ISO standard. We have not even tried to implement it here in Lund. It would eat resources. Links about OAIS:

sect1.title: Ediffah -- An search engine archival finding aids
sect1.para: Service: http://www.ediffah.org/

listitem.para: A one year projected coordinated here from Lund university
Archival Network formed by Manuscript and special collection departments at four of the country's largest research libraries.
Royal Library, Stockholm
Gothenburg University Library
Lund University Library
Uppsala University Library
with technology from LUB and National Archives.
The Ediffah service is a union catalogue covering archival collections all the member libraries.
Finding aids are encoded in Encoded Archival Description (EAD) 2003 XML DTD/Schema.
Search interface on web for end users, Z30.50 for other clients and data export in DC, Marc21 and EAD. Import in Marc21 and EAD.
OAI interface for dissemination of metadata

sect1.para: More info on the technical solution: http://www.ediffah.org/reports/software.shtml

sect1.title: Electronic theses and dissertations
sect1.para: Two services, quite ordinary ones: Xerxes and Scripta
I will only discuss them from a digital preservation perspective. Typically an electronic publishing supports at least three functions:

listitem.para: Cataloging: i.e., storing metadata.
File upload:, i.e., storing data
End user search and navigation: Search- and retrieval of data/metadata

sect2.para: Users are document authors and editorial staff (e.g., reviewers). Benefits from campuswide authentication system through LDAP. LDAP is also used for getting unique identification of authors (Lund University has more than five staff and students with the name Anders Nilsson).

sect1.title: The Internet and its business models
sect1.para: We see a number of tendencies in the global economy.

listitem.para: Some of these are general, and shared by all manufacturing industries:
The manufacturing itself becomes less and less profitable.
A steadily increasing proportion of companies' turnover comes from services rather than products.
An increasingly restlessness as regards expectations for rapid revenues from an investment made
More specifically, for the media induxstry we see:
It is becoming increasingly difficult to defend intellectual property
Steadily decreasing revenues from some (still not all) digital medial. This is due to because to the fact that marginal cost of producing additional copy is virtually zero.

sect1.title: Creative Commons and Open access is good, but...
sect1.para: Open Source Software, Open Access Media, Creative Commons, etc means to give away content, and earning your money from additional services (that's how Linus Torvalds became millionaire).
Preservation is an investment you normally cannot get a fast revenue from. What you may get is results from future research, or just patrons satisfied from reading a good book.
The question is: Who will pay preservation of things that are available for free on the Internet.
